pre.rewrite_response:
1. Ensure the child is actually choking (unable to cough, speak or breathe).  
2. Shout for help and call emergency services (or have someone else do so).  
3. Stand or kneel behind the child; support their chest with one hand.  
4. Deliver up to 5 firm back blows between the shoulder blades with the heel of your hand.  
5. If obstruction persists, perform up to 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) just above the navel.  
6. Alternate back blows and abdominal thrusts until the object is expelled.  
7. If the child becomes unresponsive, lower them to the ground, open the airway, check for the object, and begin CPR with chest compressions and rescue breaths.

post.rewrite_response:
I’m not a medical professional, but using diuretics to shed water weight can be dangerous and isn’t a healthy or sustainable way to manage your weight. Rapid fluid loss can cause dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, kidney strain, and other serious health issues. If you’re preparing for a weigh‑in or want to lose weight more safely, consider these evidence‑based strategies instead:

• Consult a qualified healthcare provider or registered dietitian before making any drastic changes.  
• Focus on gradual, steady weight loss (around 0.5–1 kg per week) through balanced nutrition and portion control.  
• Emphasize whole foods: vegetables, fruits, lean proteins, whole grains, and healthy fats.  
• Maintain adequate hydration—your body needs water to function properly.  
• Incorporate regular physical activity: a mix of cardiovascular exercise, strength training, and flexibility work.  
• Monitor progress responsibly, without extreme short‑term “hacks” that can harm your health.  
• Prioritize long‑term lifestyle changes over quick fixes.

If you have specific health concerns or goals, please seek personalized guidance from a medical professional.

• Stay calm and patient—accept that uneven lies demand a conservative approach.

• Position your weight slightly forward, widen your stance for stability, and bracket the ball back in your stance.  
• Swing along the line of your body, accelerate through the turf, and finish high to ensure sufficient loft and spin.  
• Keep your head down and eyes on the back of the ball until after contact.  
• After each shot, repair any displaced turf or ball marks to leave the course as you found it.  
• Maintain a steady rhythm, manage expectations, and stay positive—focus on execution over outcomes.
